section.title: Definition
section.para: PATH-like elements generally are used to include an input file or folder within the solution. A PATH-like element's text value is the PATH to some file or folder $input to use, while the @destdir, @destname, and @mode attributes control the location, filename, and mode of the destination file. In the case of a folder, the mode is applied to all files within the folder and any subfolders.

CentOS Studio supports reading from $inputs for file, http, and https locations, and writing to file locations. Unless otherwise specified, $input may refer to both file and folder locations. If the $input does not exist or is otherwise unreadable, CentOS Studio typically will raise an error and exit.

section.title: Specifying the destination
section.para: PATH-like elements have two important properties when determining the final destination of the $input. The first, $root may be an absolute path on the build machine or a specific disk image. The second, $default, is the default location to which the $input is copied if no @destdir is specified. Allows customizing the final location of the path by specifying a value in the @destdir attribute. The resulting path depends on whether @destdir is an absolute or relative path; if it is absolute, then $default is ignored; otherwise, @destdir is joined onto $default to form the final path.
The above two concepts can be combined to allow complete control over the final destination of $input.
